Writ.definition: a letter that was issued in the name of the English monarch from Anglo-Saxon times to declare his grants

1.definition: a common-law writ formerly used to restore property held by another to its rightful owner

2.definition: a writ granted as a matter of right comparein this entry

alias writ.definition: a writ issued upon the failure of a previous one

alternative writ.definition: a writ commanding one to perform a mandated act or else to show cause why the act need not be performed comparein this entry

extraordinary writ.definition: a writ granted as an extraordinary remedy at the discretion of the court in its jurisdiction over officials or inferior tribunals called alsosee also,,,,,comparein this entry
extraordinary writ.note: Extraordinary writs were originally writs exercised by royal prerogative.

judicial writ.definition: a writ issued by a court under its own seal for judicial purposes in the course of a proceeding or to enforce a judgment comparein this entry

original writ.definition: a writ formerly used in England that issued out of chancery as the means of bringing a suit and defendant before the court comparein this entry
original writ.note: The original writ was superseded by the summons in 1873.

peremptory writ.definition: a writ (as of mandamus) that presents an absolute order without the alternative to show cause [aof prohibition] comparein this entry

writ of error.definition: a common-law writ directing an inferior court to remit the record of an action to the reviewing court in order that an error of law may be corrected if it exists
writ of error.note: The writ of error has been largely abolished and superseded by the appeal.

writ of error coram nobis.definition: a writ calling the attention of the trial court to facts which do not appear on the record despite the exercise of reasonable diligence by the defendant and which if known and established at the time a judgment was rendered would have resulted in a different judgment [petitioned for aon the ground that newly discovered evidence exonerated him] called also
writ of error coram nobis.writ of error coram nobis: on the ground that newly discovered evidence exonerated him] called also
